contextId.glQuote: their vine comes from the vine of Sodom, and from the fields of Gomorrah

contextId.occurrenceNote: Moses continues comparing the enemies of the people of Israel to grapevines that produce poisonous fruit and wine. This means their enemies are wicked. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Their wine is the poison of serpents and the cruel venom of asps

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of the bad things that will happen to his enemies as if the bad things were people running eagerly to punish them. Alternate translation: "I will punish them quickly" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the things that are to come on them will hurry to happen

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh speaks of arrows as if they were people to whom he could give alcohol and make them drunk, and of a sword as if it were a person who was so hungry that he would eat an animal before draining the blood out. These metaphors are metonyms for a soldier using arrows and a sword to kill many enemies. This in turn is a metaphor for Yahweh killing his enemies in war. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: I will make my arrows drunk with blood, and my sword will devour flesh with the blood

contextId.occurrenceNote: Long days are a metaphor for a long life. See how you translated these words in [Deuteronomy 4:26](../04/26.md). Alternate translation: "be able to live a long time" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: prolong your days

contextId.occurrenceNote: Moses compares Yahweh to the rising sun. Alternate translation: "When Yahweh came from Sinai, he looked to them like the sun when it rises from Seir and shines out from Mount Paran" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Yahweh came from Sinai and rose from Seir upon them. He shined out from Mount Paran

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase is used twice as a metaphor. Alternate translation: "rise up to fight ... cause any more trouble" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: rise up ... rise up

contextId.occurrenceNote: This metaphor is of a man putting his hand on the head of a son and asking God to bless the son. The man here is Yahweh. Alternate translation: "May Yahweh bless Joseph as a father blesses his son" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Let the blessing come on the head of Joseph

contextId.occurrenceNote: The ox is a metaphor for something large and strong. The word "firstborn" is a metaphor for honor. Alternate translation: "People will honor Joseph's descendants, who are many and powerful" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: The firstborn of an ox, majestic is he

contextId.occurrenceNote: The horn is a metaphor for strength. Alternate translation: "he is as strong as" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: his horns are the horns of

contextId.occurrenceNote: Pushing with his horns is a metaphor for strength. Alternate translation: "He is so strong that he will push" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: With them he will push

contextId.occurrenceNote: The Hebrew word translated "suck" here refers to how a baby nurses at its mother's breast. It means the people will gain wealth from the sea like a baby gets milk from its mother. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: For they will suck the abundance of the seas

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Dan are strong like a lion cub, and they attack their enemies who live in Bashan. You can make clear the understood information. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-ellipsis]])
contextId.glQuote: Dan is a lion cub that leaps out from Bashan

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh being pleased with Naphtali is spoken of as if "favor" were food that Naphtali ate until he was no longer hungry. Alternate translation: "who has all the good things he desires because Yahweh is pleased with him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: satisfied with favor

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is an image of Yahweh riding on clouds through the sky like a king on his chariot riding through a battlefield. Alternate translation: "rides through the heavens like a king rides through a battlefield ... on the clouds like a king on his chariot" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: rides through the heavens ... on the clouds

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words "everlasting arms" are a metaphor for Yahweh's promise to protect his people forever. Alternate translation: "he will support and take care of his people forever" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: underneath are the everlasting arms

contextId.occurrenceNote: The dew is spoken of as being so much that it is as if it were raining. Possible meanings are 1) Moses is blessing Israel, "may much dew cover the land like rain" or 2) Moses is telling what will happen in the future, "much dew will cover the land like rain." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: let his heavens drop dew

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "shield" is a metaphor for Yahweh protecting and defending the Israelites. The abstract noun "help" can be translated as a verb. Alternate translation: "the one who protects you and helps you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.glQuote: the shield of your help

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "sword" is a metaphor for the power to kill with the sword in order to win battles. Alternate translation: "the one who enables you to win battles and so have majesty" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the sword of your majesty

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks as if Joshua were a container and the spirit were a physical object that could be put into a container. Alternate translation: "Yahweh enabled Joshua ... to be very wise" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Joshua ... was full of the spirit of wisdom
